posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9497340
I love both games as a duology but playing the first game again is kinda awkward because the writing seems so juvenile at times in comparison to 2. However it's still a good game and gets credit for establishing the new setting and having a memorable cast and campaign.
The second game fleshes out and expands upon pretty much every aspect while also having more subtle and mature writing, although the game's conclusion was clearly rushed and in need of a sequel that never happened.
I especially liked how your actions and choices in 2 will affect your companions, turning them further to the dark or light side depending on whether they like you or not. You also get a lot more chances to roleplay your character's backstory and motivations.
Basically all you need to identify the tone and direction of both games is to listen to their respective soundtracks. They sound almost completely different from each other while also staying faithful to Star Wars. 1 is a classic hero's journey which is very satisfying by the end, while 2 is more of an introspection on the player character and their actions and beliefs throughout the game. They offer different roleplaying experiences from each other, which I would urge people to embrace rather than wishing one was more like the other. 2 for example doesn't have an epic satisfying ending like 1 does which leaves a sour taste in peoples' mouths, which is sad because they should really be appreciative of the amazing role-playing journey present in that game.
Anyway, both are really good games and worth playing for RPG fans even if you don't give a shit about Star Wars. In fact both of them are better than all of the Star Wars films.

posts.com:
The Doomslayer in GMOTA is interesting because it's probably the first time a mod adresses the Sentinel from nuDoom and "expands" on them (because they barely had material at the time before Eternal)
Mostly because a lot of 2016 inspired mods are essentially "backporting" things that exist (even if not 100% faithfully) and GMOTA as a mod has a specific concept in mind, so the nuDoom/Slayer stuff (and the made up stuff for it) is a minor part
But between how limited Doom Eternal's modding is and some drawings people made of "original demon designs inspired by DE", i wonder if it'd take some "new Doom in old Doom" mod or Slayer's Testaments to "expand" the aesthetic/mechanisms of the new games
Like, imagine if someone did a small wad inspired by Urdak and made up a bunch of enemies based off the Maykrs, with a few based off actual concept art
And this is if a "classic take" on Urdak and Sentinel doesn't get creative, since the UAC/Hell are also portrayed differently in these new games
I remember Wad overdose on Doomworld doing "sprite" versions of someone's made up Eternal designs
I actually wonder about D3 having "original demons" too because stuff like the Arachnotron is based off official concept art and you had a PE and Baron that looked like modified Caco's and Barons
Pic related aged thanks to TAG2 but i also think the purple goo attack could suit a different demon design

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nintendo 64 games run at high resolution
Majority of N64 games run at standard 320x240 resolution. Some games support higher resolution with the expansion pack but less than a dozen reach 640x480. For the rest it's some weird resolution like 400×440 or 480x360.
https://nintendo.fandom.com/wiki/Nintendo_64_Expansion_Pak
>Nintendo 64 games have higher polygon count than PS1 games
N64 supports 160000 polygons per second with standard microcode. If you switch off some hardware features like Z-buffering, N64 theoretically can reach 500000-600000 polygons per second but these would be very basic unfiltered and untextured polygons.
PS1 has 180000 for textured polygons and 360000 polygons per second for untextured polygons. Most games use a combination of two.
In practice, no N64 game has a polycount outside of PS1 capabilities.
>Nintendo 64 games have bad textures because of cart size limitations
Only partially true. The most significant bottleneck is 4kb texture cache which takes CPU cycles to be updated. In short, the bigger textures you use, the worse framerate you have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Basically when games and technology started specifically aiming for a photorealistic picture, is when "retro" truly ended. To me what we call retro - both 2D and early 3D - is not about dates but rather about artistic merits of working around major technical limitations, which is what made those games so good. When every game looked absolutely different and unique because they were all hyper-stylized artistic depictions of reality seen through the prism of artistry of creative people. Not so much anymore when 90% of the entire development process goes towards making everything look how it does in real life - which is, you know, the same. When the 7th gen started we didn't just gain things like upgrades in storage space and resolution, for the first time in history we started progressively losing things, losing artistry, because there were no more major technical limitations to overcome. More and more elements started becoming token. So much so that we saw the rise of tertiary elements like online becoming more popular than the games themselves.

>>9484063
>Cinematic platformers, Mortal Kombat
Nothing even remotely like that. They used digitized actors because it was easier compared to drawing sprites. The end result was just as cartoony tho, they never even attempted to deliberately strive for any sort of photorealism.
>the whole FMV fad
That was a completely separate convergent evolutionary dead-end. There were VHS-based games and so on. At that point you can say board games are photorealistic because you played them irl.

No, only in the 7th gen did games start deliberately and en-mass, which is key here, strive for photorealism in one way or another.

>>9484032
I wouldn't mind this definition but I also don't mind including GC/PS2/Faggotbox either. Looking back with the benefit of hindsight regarding what I hate the most about games & consoles today, I see that generation as being relatively pure. Experimental market-poking and prodding happened, but it wasn't the norm, and I fully expect to have to deal with these being called retro by my weaker brethren en masse someday.

With the Wii/PS3/Faggotbox360 they were becoming more committed to their modern, forwadd-looking hardware identity, but they were still only experimenting with the rot. It had evolved from a question of permissions to a question of facilitation. It was the Switch/PS4/FaggotboxOne generation where all three companies had fully committed to modern rot concepts. Their hardware angle was set and leaned into, their policy and strategy on the brave new werld of microtransactions, unfinished beta AAA releases, bloatgramming, and various other consumer abuses that old games lack were set and normalized.

Maybe retro can be defined by exactly in which ways companies abused consumers. Back in the day your lives were tied to a real life quarter that you popped into the machine, so the market wanted HARD games that you learned to play by dying repetitively. When the move to console came it wasn't long till this shifted. Instead of incessantly killing you (unpopular with millenials), the games were filled with meaningless content and time wasters. Companies believed that time spent playing on a home console was a sales leader driving new game purchases. Sounds right to me. Eventually it shifted again though, and everything reminds me of the itunes/googleplaystore now. I'm almost done typing. Microsoft is gay and if you pay them money you are also gay, good night /vr/

The actual retro is arcades and the age before the mass spread of personal computers and consoles. When games were programmed in universities by enthusiasts.

The "problem" lies with the board's name because if it actually was for retro games only it would've had activity comparable to /po/.

>Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

A new generations model, not based on years, but on hardware and gameplay:
1 - Pre-NES.
2 - NES-TG16-SMS.
3 - SNES-SMD-GB-PS1.
4 - PS1-N64-SAT.

7 - Xbone-PS4 thru today.
Nintendo since Wii has dropped a generation behind the pack. I think the major problem with the previous model was basing it off of Nintendo's consoles as if they represented the pack, when really they are notable outliers. Look at them today especially, their main system is a handheld! To say the switch is the representative of modern gaming isn't entirely accurate, it more represents the previous generation's staying power.
Look at human beings. There are 4 or 5 generations living today. They are each different, but one's inception is not necessarily the other's demise. a generation lasts as long as it is able to compete for market space. 8bit did it for a whole decade on a puny B&W screen, but it stuck it out!

>Gen 7 (Early HD) - 360, PS3, Vita, Wii U, Switch

Hell no. It's more of a Gen 6.5 console.
If you're saying that the Xbox could not handle the Vita's 960x544p resolution, then I beg to differ, as there are some 720p and even 1080i games on Xbox.
Also, the Switch is more of a Gen 7.5 console, as it's much more powerful than the Wii U, PS3 and Xbox 360, but not as powerful as the Gen 8 consoles.
For starters, the Crysis Trilogy looks and plays much better on Switch than on PS360.

I would also add the 3DO to Gen 4.5, the Philips CD-i is more Gen 4.
The Atari Jaguar is also part of Gen 4.5.
I don't know which generation the Virtual Boy would be but it would probably be Gen 3.5. The graphics are nearly as detailed as the SNES, but it's monochrome and the music is still clearly 8-Bit.

Atari 5200 and 7800 are also Gen 2. 7800 was outdated for its time and is part of why it failed, but not as much as the 5200.
The Lynx is Gen 3.
Commodore 64 is also Gen 3.

Calling the PS Vita a Gen 7 console is inaccurate.
The Vita is nowhere near as powerful as a PS3.

And even the PS2 had 1080i in some games like Gran Turismo 4. And that game was not native 1080i.
Lastly, the PS Vita had a 960x544 screen and most games were in that resolution, which is in this limbo of being too high to be SD but too low to be HD.
There are games with lower resolutions, though, and the Vita TV can be hacked to render select games like Persona 4 Golden and Catherine: Full Body in 1280x720p or 1920x1080i.

>>9477134
Japan has an inclination to do stories of the young because of initial post-WWII ideals. They were slower in growth and did not lend to people of that generation immediately creating new stories. It took Japan longer, like the first Godzilla struggled to get made because of anti-Japanese sentiment. It impacted them culturally and they didn't have a boom. By the time thedid rapidly expand, it was younger people making the stories, who had a different perception of WWII and Japan as a whole. since the 60's and 70's Japan has just very heavily leaned into using young people in media.

On the contrast to what the west was doing. The growth of hollywood never stopped during the war, only shifted. And the stream of stories was always on the middle aged. It wasn't till the 50's that the west also started incorporating young people into their stories.

I think FFX suffers from some slight issues, as far as intent and facts though. Auron is supposed to old at age 35 and even refers to himself as young 10 years ago, when he was 25. Yet we have a maester who has served for some 70 years. I think what happens is characters get designed and created and then put into a story and not organically written. So it's part of the overall media franchise machine.

Lulu's path is a unique one, as for most of the game lulu is your only nuker and you can get magic boost weapons for kimahri and he can help clean up enemies weak to that.

Wakka and Auron paths are fine, but don't offer that much, unless you just wanted to use Kimahri over those characters.

You just let the OPL desktop software a folder on your computer (mine's on a laptop) and set it up to be sharable. Pic related, there's only three folders you care about and the full art asset set can be downloaded pre-formatted at under 200mb

From my cheat sheet:

>04/26/2021

>This is a SHARED FOLDER FOR OPEN PS2 LOADER, CONNECTED VIA ETHERNET CABLE
>-I configured a static IP address on my network adapter for this; you'll have
>to go to network and sharing > change adapter settings > ethernet > IPV4
>to convert it back to dynamic IP from current static

>I changed share settings for home and public; might want to lock those back down.

>If you want to remove the shared file path (C:\***\PS2SMB), go to properties/sharing/advanced sharing/uncheck 'share this folder'

>>9484171
OPL is short for Open PS2 Loader. It's software you run on your PS2 that lets you boot games from an internal hard drive, a USB drive or via your network using SMB.
It's pretty sweet, honestly. You can buy a memory card online for maybe $15 tops that's preloaded everything you need to run it on your PS2. You just plug the memory card into either slot before the console boots and you're good to go.
Setting up OPL itself is another matter entirely, but it's really well documented.

posts.com:

It's also an accompanying managerial application what you use to properly format ISOs (IE, make sure they're named with the proper formatting), manage art assets, and convert CD-format PS2 games (Bin+cue) to ghetto ISOs you can play through the utility

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484643
>Is there any difference between the IDE to SATA converters? Obviously it's all chinkshit, but is it all pretty much the same?
I noticed there's some that don't have the master/slave switch. This is a thing I became aware while homebrewing my Xbox. I don't know if that would cause any problems. Due to the low price the only option is just to try them out.

>I think I saw that you could use a 3.5 or a 2.5 drive, but I assume a 2.5 would be better for the space. I just don't know what all of this looks like once its in the guts of the machine.
I use SATA drives (2.5 ones). This is how it looks. It kind of dangles from the network adapter. As long as you're not moving the PS2 around there is no danger of it falling off. Somebody sold 3D printer "holders" to make it more sturdy, but I haven't had any problems in a year of using this setup.

>And for HDDs, is there an upper limit on specs that the PS2 even benefits from?
I think the limit is 2 TB but that's really overkill. The main issue is that any HDD you obtain has to be detectable by the PS2 for formatting. It may well be that the expensive HDD you buy simply won't be detected and there is nothing you can do. My suggestion is to salvage some SATA HDDs from old laptops or second-hand stores. I got two 500 GB and one 320 GB drives this way and only cost me $30 from a guy on facebook marketplace. All of them worked, luckily.

The PS2 won't benefit from higher speeds since most games have tied logic to the PS2 reading speed, so its capped.

The current program used for feeding games to the drive is called HDL-Batch. It has been updated this year and I literally used it yesterday. Now it has an user interface and can tell you if the ISO is corrupt or if its already in the drive etc. You format the drive in the PS2, get it out and connect it to the PC with an USB to SATA cable (very cheap), the program dectects the drive and you just select the games you want to install.

>Would a 3.5" drive still dangle, or sit more flush?
The 3.5 IDE drive will just fill the space so there would be no dangling. The space was made for those in mind.
I opted for the 2.5 SATA drives due to the issues of:
- needing the SATA to IDE adapter OR the original PS2 network adapter.
- needing to get an IDE to USB for the PC (the IDE needs it's own power so it will turn on in the Xbox/PS2 but not when you connect it to the PC with the SATA to IDE adapter).
- the internet scared me with stories of IDE drives dying out of the blue.
- the current abundance of SATA drives being thrown for pennies by people who don't know better and me being unable to find an IDE drive that wasn't being sold full-price/new.

>Oh, you don't just do all that through Explorer file management? I guess I didn't notice that when reading this stuff.
Windows will just not even acknowledge you added connected a drive if it's formatted for PS2. Yes. It's confusing.

>>9485430
Obviously the hard drive goes in the PS2.
OPL has an option to format it for PS2 use, regardless what was in it before.
It just needs to recognize it (there's a website for compatibilities but its incomplete and given the unlikeness of finding the exact drive it's better to get it for cheap).

Once formatted you can add games to it. The fastest is to take the drive out and connect via USB to the PC.
Windows won't recognize the drive, but if you use HDL batch it will appear there. There you just select the ISOs and BIN/CUEs you want to add and it loads them up.
There are other ways to add stuff like network or USB but that's slow as fuck.

If you read this thread there have been several posts with good resources about where to get started. Basically, you'll need a memory card with Free MCBoot preinstalled (you can get these on eBay or Amazon) and you'll need to install OPL Manager on your PC to manage your games. If you have a fat PS2, you should spend a little more money and get a hard drive set up for it. If you have a slim you should stick to playing games over ethernet. You can play games over USB on ether model, but it's not as good as the other methods.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9493123
I think it's a matter of people wanting a hassle free solution, like the original xbox or wii. I have around 950 PS2 games on my 2TB HDD and just a couple of games didn't work, which was solved by using an older version of OPL.

OPL has some plugins enabled by default and even though they can be useful, it breaks a good % of games. One unlocks the read speed of the HDD so games load as fast as possible and the other is called IGR (In-Game Reset), which enables you to reset the console with a combination of buttons. For games that don't boot, you have to turn off one of these plugins. Problem is, many people don't know you can have game-specific configs, so they see a game that doesn't work and call it quits.

Subtitles in games like Shenmue (where subtitles are difference colors, not just white/black) look really awful, but otherwise this new Trinitron is absolute king for 8-bit and 16-bit games. I forget just how good Hard Corps looks on a big tube.
I read up about how to go about fixing convergence though and it looks like there's three ways to go about it, depending on the gravity of the issue.
>Move the Horizontal alignment physical thingy inside the chassis.
>Move the Vertical alignment rings around the yoke itself.
>Stick more convergence strips inside the yoke, maybe even move magnets around.
In my case, the convergence is only really off on the borders of the image, so I only really need to play around with the "convergence strips", whatever that is. Will look into some home-made strips though, since I really doubt I'll be able to find these things on sale at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485672
>That's not how TVL works.
Stupid faggot, that's exactly how it works

TVL = Horizontal Resolution
SNES/Genesis after PAR adjustment = 292x224

Assuming no overscan you can display all detail with 292TVL and and anything more than that and it looks oversharpened.
But CRTs always have overscan so you can never get it perfect.

Example
Top
15 inch consumer CRT component

Bottom
500 line PVM 14 inch RGB

The lower TVL looks far far better
But even that isn't perfect since you have screen-door effect because of the dot pitch being bigger than the pixel pitch.
The only way to achieve perfection is near-neighbour scaling into 12000-20000 PPI displays which is still a long way off.

>>9488437
Oh hey good timing, you asked right as I was checking back on this thread
I had two wired Retrofighters Brawler64s that crapped out on me. Basically the analog stick started dropping inputs, so for example if you were running forward as Link in OoT he would stop and start - essentially unusable. Both had the exact same problem.
Unfortunately they both had fallen just outside the warranty window, and their support didn't even reply when I sent them like a "Hey, anything I can try to do to fix these?"
About a year later someone on twitter was asking about them, and I outlined that whole chain of events to them and said that I don't recommend them at all. From that tweet, their PR/customer support team reached out to me and ultimately actually shipped me two of the newer wireless versions by way of apology. And the wireless one has held up a lot better than the originals. At least, so far.
So maybe the takeaway is, they used to be utter crap, and now are (hopefully) a lot better. The analog stick on all of these these is just kind of weird though.

In the interim I used the wired Retro-Bit Tribute64 (which is modeled after the famous Hori N64 controller) and I actually liked this a lot better than any of the Brawler64s. The only problem with these is that the connector has an absolute death grip on the controller port, which is why I switched back to the wireless Brawler64 for right now - since I didn't want to be unplugging and replugging that controller all the time, and wireless controllers just keep things a bit more tidy. You know how it is.

There is an N64 controller purist on this board who will tell you that the analog stick sensitivity and deadzones of any of these 3rd party controllers is crap compared to the original - he's got charts and whatnot to back it up. He's probably right, but it's never really bothered me and or caused any real problems.

Of these I'd recommend the Tribute64 first.

>>9490051
>>9491313
Safest bet would be to open the thing and check all capacitors with an ESR calculator. Replace the bad ones with new capacitors of the same specifications and pray that it works.
When it comes to these old machines, capacitors are almost always the suspect number one because they tend to fail earlier and when they do fail (and they will), they bulge up and start leaking on the main board, so you want to take care of that as soon as humanly possible.
If you aren't one for soldering, you could ask someone to do it, but it's questionable whether professionals will work on CRTs nowadays. Definitely a good skill to have though or, in my case, know someone who does that kind of thing.

generally with gen 7 imo you want to be on a modern TV because all of gen 7 supported 480p (and beyond), and your CRT will likely only support 480i
So while gen 7 consoles can output a 480i signal that works on consumer CRTs, the software was pretty much all designed for 480p (or 720p, in the case of most PS3 games afaik). So right out of the gate on a PS3, you're taking a huge quality loss when using a CRT just because of the signals it can handle.

Pretty much all of the "Wow, this looks way better than my old CRT!" talk comes from back in the day when people were viewing a 480i signal on their CRT and then switched to a 480p signal on their flatscreen during gen 7. And I don't really think there are any games where you'd be like, "Now THIS. THIS game was MADE for a CRT!!", that's all up to personal taste.

Anon, please don't do this. As other people have stated, you can find a great TV set for free or around 50 dollars or less price range, if you actually take the time to look. Sure, that ship has sailed a long time ago, but there is still a gluten of old CRT TV’s still out there in the wild. CRT’s can fail and need costly repairs and you don’t want to be stuck with that bill if you can avoid it. Let alone when you are talking about dropping a 1,000 dollars or so on a 20 year old TV set. >Why the fuck does literally no one make a modern CRT?
It's because it's just too expensive. No one manufactures CRT TV anymore. The production cost was so low (insanely low) in the late 2000's for that reason alone. You could pick a mid to semi high grade CRT for 100 - 300 bucks brand new.
> I'm kind of treating these as a real TV purchase, not just for retro games like I said.
>I just want to also be able watch movies and TV shows on it in acceptable quality.
Be prepared to make some compromises you might not be thinking about. I have a Sylvania 6420FF (20 inches) I use for my bedroom TV and I don't think most modern consumers would care for that. If you want to use normal TV that way (over the air TV), you are going to need a converter box unless you have cable. I think CRT TV’s have their uses for sure (retro), but you need to use them in the best way possible. Think of it as a hobby TV, not your main one. They look great using old video game systems and DVD’s, but if you are approaching the HD stuff, it’s really not the best use for it. You'll be looking at 16:9 bars.

>>9490640
This. The logical conclusion is to get the correct controller for each of the consoles you plan to emulate. Because of the gulf in quality between first party controllers and third party USB clones, you're going to want first party original controllers and of course because there is no way to connect them to a PC, high quality adapters for them so for every emulator you'll have to drop around $25-50 + $25-45 for controllers and adapters. Before you know it you'll be knee deep in a bin full of controllers with different dongles. Hope you got high quality ones, chink ones don't even last 5 cycles.

So the cost of free emulation after a $1000 + PC is pretty high. That's about $80 for each console you want to emulate. Now you just have to spend time configuring every game for every emulator, setting up hacks so they actually run, pining for fixes in nightly releases and tweaking CRT shaders.

Will it be worth it?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9490375
I know the answer to this. It's objectively the PS3 controller and I'll tell you why. Xbox controllers don't have the gyroscope or whatever it's called (six axis motion?) and the PS4 controller comes close, but it doesn't have pressure sensitive face buttons. Most controllers have pressure sensitive triggers, but that's it. Basically, this is the only controller that allows you to lightly press any button and also registers tilt. Why does this matter you ask? Because there are a few games where this is absolutely needed. If I remember correctly, the Metal Gear solid games from the ps2 needed this and when they were ported to xbox they needed to redo these mechanics. Also you can emulate the ps3 nowdays so there's Heavely Sword, etc. The only downside is that it doesn't use a micro usb like the PS4 controller, it uses a mini usb. But get the cable and you're set.
>ps3controller.jpg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490142
anon, even the best-optimized 3D games on it had low framerates and low res. and most of them were crappy racers with tiny drawing distance.
i think there's a whole breed of retards who think GBA being 32 bit meant it had same specs as PSX, and that Nintendo just "didn't work hard enough on 3d". except unlike PSX, GBA had no real GPU or 3D hardware. if you understand what this means, you know you will need the CPU to render everything, and it will be done at a very slow speed.
pair this with the need for batteries, tiny res, lack of analog, etc., and you will understand why it didn't have much 3D.
and yes, surely, 20 years later some dedicated autists managed to put Tomb Raider on GBA, but no one would have time and money to bother with this back in the day when the system's life cycle was only 3 years.
instead, you got smooth good 2D and actually good 2D games. virtually of the 3D GBA titles I've played were shovelware racers, gimmicky trash and yuroshit. so I'm glad that GBA devs went with 2D instead of chasing 3D.

>>9490576
Actual poster, I'll elaborate. Hl1 was lightning in a bottle, it came at the perfect time and introduced innovate things to the FPS genre. It had some "magic", as bad as a decriptor that is. The weapons felt good, the movement was just right, etc. It got a bit boring near the end, but the rest was peak 90's gaming. HL2 on the other hand was just a pretty good FPS game. There's nothing WRONG with it exactly, but it's just not very special compared to contemporary games. I remember playing Doom3 at the time and I enjoyed that at least as much as HL2, and Doom3 is not a fantastic game by any means. Many weapons in HL2 feel off and sloppy (the pistol that goes "paff paff paff", the smg that just spits out bullets in a weird spray without any real recoil in between bullets but just a random cone of dispersion, etc). The characters and story feel forced, HL did not have a linear story you had to follow, the story was just a backdrop to the action. In HL2 you are forced to sit through what is essentially cutscenes with a lot of "who cares" characters that you are supposed to care about. It's also full of gimmicks, especially related to the physics.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9491679
The original is a pretty good game in its own right.
Something to note is that the UE1 engine games (Unreal, Unreal Tournament (sequel) have some compatibility problems on modern systems. Patch both with their latest Old Unreal patches and this is my subjective opinion, but stick with the legacy Galaxy audio system for sound. The other audio systems have different quirks that affect how effects and music are mixed and propagated in the games and they don't feel quite right to people that have played them before, someone new might not care but still the right choice imo.

Also the games are supposed to have some neat looking volumetric fogsl effects, but sometimes the games automatically disable it because of outdated hardware checks. You'll have to read about how to force them back on in the advanced preferences menu of the engine if they get disabled.

Unreal Tournament has a full campaign ladder mode for solo play that takes you through pretty much all the game's content. UT:GOTY features a new Skaarj hybrid team and a revised campaign ladder with different maps, omitting an iconic map 'Barricade' that I actually kind of liked. There's a one line setting in an .ini file for switching the game back into its original 1999 state if you want. All maps can be found in the practice menu for custom matches.

UT2k4 has a slightly less developed campaign mode that only gives you a fraction of the total content. Use Instant Action to explore the full game.

Unreal 2 is mediocre, but it doesn't suck, imo.

So on that alone I'd probably play 99 for 2k4 first depending on what looks better to you and then if you like one try the other one. Both have surprisingly competent singleplayer campaigns. UT99 still has a multiplayer scene but unless you are experienced in this type of game you'll probably spend most of your time eating shit.

Unreal and Unreal 2 are also very good games in their own right. The original Unreal is a bit of an odd FPS in that the pacing is really slow, but it's also absolutely brilliant visually and if you get into it the atmosphere is fantastic. It's fairly long, though, and if you don't like it in the first five hours you can safely drop it. It's definitely not for everyone.

I haven't played Unreal 2 since it launched, but I liked it quite a bit at that time. Come to think of it, that's basically the only thing I remember about it.


(So the racist Quake guy doesn't waste his time responding to my posts: Yes, Q3A is a better game than any of the Unreal Tournament games. I'd also say the original Quake is better than any UT. That doesn't change the fact that it's still a very strong series with multiple exceptional games.)

I am always surprised that people don't mention this. This is one of the best things about what UT3 brought back: the feeling that your weapon was actually powerful. UT99 had that going on really well, the weapons were pretty overpowered in all honesty, but they were all OP so it was only a matter of grabbing the right weapon. Then UT2k4 tries to nerf things down a LOT for its team-based gameplay, and how they wanted to be a bit more like Quake (you can really feel it with the rocket launcher, where in UT99 it actually has a small delay before firing, making it feel really meaty and force you to hard-read enemy movement, and it has a bigass splash damage radius, but in UT2k4 they made the splash damage really small like a Quake 3 rocket. I just feel like the actual core gameplay in 2k4 is meh, meaning the deathmatching. The actual team-based modes are actually really fun, and great! ...but they don't feel like Unreal. UT2003 also doesn't feel like Unreal that much, but even worse about it because that game was really pushing the whole objective-based gameplay and had severe balancing issues.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I also prefer the first two games. More iconic moments and enemy/boss variety. Single plane beat 'em ups are kind of underrated.

Making a belt scroller was a natural evolution at that point but the combat is just kind of decent. By the way, I'm mainly talking about the Japanese version (which is in English).

>>9496637
>also that damn time limit is annoying, you can't enjoy the brawl.

This is one things they changed with the localization. The time limit is much shorter. This forces you to take the shortest route to get the good ending. In the Japanese version, the non-linear setup of the game feels like it's just there to just give you some extra replay value and variety on different playthroughs. You'll have plenty of time to get to the end in time no matter which route as long as you play well, except maybe on Game Master difficulty.

They also made changes to the combat, halving the damage of your regular combo but turning your spin kick special attack into a super move which does huge amounts of damage. In the Japanese version, the spin kick is just a regular "get off me" move like in Final Fight. As a result the most effective way to play the localized version is to spam it. You can even pretty much ignore your mutant mode. In the Japanese version it's better to use your entire toolset and strategize for when you want to spend the resource to turn into a mutant.

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Duke_Nukem_Forever

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

>>9485398
Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9484987
The Dreamcast has a lot of really solid games, but honestly the majority of them have been ported to the PC or other consoles. Unless you like shooters or fighting games, I'd recommend thinking about getting a Saturn instead. It has far more exclusives.

I had one in highschool, me and a bunch of friends all grabbed one when TRU was blowing them out for $50 on clearance. I remember playing NBA 2K1 and making a custom team filled with me and all of my friends, and we'd play games in four player mode. All of the created players based on us had all of their stats set up to maximize dunking, so we'd just do dunks after dunks on the AI teams, it was hilarious.

We'd also do shit like make custom parks for THPS2, and then bring our VMUs to school and trade parks with each other via the VMU to VMU file transfer. Shit really felt like the future back then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tried to convince myself that the Dreamcast was worth it.

Here's what I learned:

- GDEMU isn't worth it, most rips are ok, the only game that I played that had an issue was Bust a Move (WinCE) (can't play bgm), but it's a simple 2d game so I just emulate it instead. ask yourself, do I really need to pay +$100 usd to switch between 10 games? or just buy 10-15 cheap cds instead.
- Shenmue is worth it because it looks different than the remaster on PC, and the new redub mod was recently released. But the game has some slowdowns. Check the overclock mod if you care about more performance.
- The fan is NOISY, if you care about noise check the noctua fan mod.
- Lightgun games, if you have CRT TV go for it, LCD lightgun mods are expensive.
- Fighting games, worth playing, look and sound great, go for it unless you want to use an arcade stick.
- Resident Evil, Skies of Arcadia, Jet Set Radio, worth it.
- Soul Reaver has better models and effects that the PC version, worth it.
- Tony Hawk 2 runs at 30fps. Xbox has better textures and it's a different game (2X), better version, but dreamcast has the "proper classic" version.
- Rayman 2 worth it because it's closer to the "classic" version.
- The 480p picture quality makes this console a MUST. It's amazing to play 90s games in this resolution.
- DCHDMI isn't worth it. I got a $25 usd VGA box from AliExpress that also outputs HDMI and the picture quality is amazing, I have an OLED B7 that actually does a great job upscaling the 480p output.
- The controller is a hit and miss, the camera control in Soul Reaver with the D-pad is just horrendous with that layout.

So: small library, but amazing picture quality, and iconic games, IMO expensive mods like DCHDMI and GDEMU are a waste of money, check the library, you will have a great time with this console, but probably just with a dozen of games lol, currently playing Skies of Arcadia and Soul Reaver.

Yeah, that's a bald-headed lie. I did the math for shits and giggles. Built a helix stack with a station at top and bottom, took ride length for that segment over number of turns to get circumference and hence radius of curvature: 11.8m. Convert 130kph to m/s and a = v^2/r = 11.2g.

Taking a two-unit (3m) high volume of space to be a cube, a medium turn spans, square-center to square-center, 5 squares for a 15m diameter and 17.7g.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The circular force would be split via bank between lateral and vertical as sides of a triangle - meaning the values obey the pythagorean theorem (a^2+b^2=c^2). So the more conservative/accurate figure of 11g could be softened to something like 7.5g and 8g. Still no bueno.

>The original complaint [...] is that jewcoasters are bad because the game is piss easy
That's not what they said, you tremendous faggot. They said difficulty isn't an excuse for using them.

RCT is a theme park simulator. They're called scam or jew coasters for a reason. The 'pay us for nothing' gag only worked for traveling shows that bilked a batch of locals and moved on to the next group of rubes. They're antithetical to the game and exist only as a consequence of tuning it to not fuck over legitimate things like small launched/shuttled coasters and family coasters. They're an exploit and make no sense outside of cheesing game systems. That's why they're bad.

>suddenly
You have advanced from tremendous faggot to egregious faggot. That isn't moving the goalposts or 'no that doesn't count!' A scenario that is not only made easier by an exploit but was designed to require an exploit is arguably badly designed. One can make the case that an unintended design consequence (an emergent exploit) can be folded into the game's design as a mechanic, but that hardly applies here. You either know it or you don't and there's no subtlety, cleverness, creativity, etc in doing it.

Now go choke on cocks somewhere else without bothering us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Consoles had to think for really long time when playing at higher levels. Atari 2600 chess has a meme highest difficulty where the opponent thinks for multiple hours to play its first turn because it has to bruteforce thorough all possible plays before taking a decision. That's why the most powerful co-processor on SNES, a 21 MHz 32-bit ARM chip was used only once in a shogi game of all things.

So I've been trying to understand, how exactly is Mega Drive viewed in Japan? Anyone who can contribute on this topic?
I've been looking at the game sales to get a general idea. There doesn't seem to be much data on game sales available, but the 2 lists Ive found paint a pretty similar picture—and it's pretty interesting.
Ironically, the #1 game on MD supposedly was Puyo Puyo. And looks like Sonic was quite popular on it, ending the meme that "no one knows Sonic in Japan"—MD simply sold like shit, and Sonic with it.
That said, the top was clearly dominated by RPGs, with Shining and Phantasy Star, and even games like Langrisser 2. No wonder Sega later wanted to have more RPGs on the platform.
Mega CD sold relatively well in Japan, so a few games for it made it to the top, like, interestingly, Silpheed, an even a fucking Night Trap.
Anyway, it's pretty surprising to see a list like this. Then again, it's clear that action games were far more popular in the West than in Japan, and it clearly had more appeal there with stuff like Streets of Rage, Golden Axe, Comix Zone, all the platformers, Mortal Kombat, sports games, and so on.

A chart comparing the console sales also sheds some light on the subject. Basically, MD was more or less doing ok, competing with PCE until around 1991-92. But then, SFC released and quickly overtook both of them. Sega CD helped slightly, but then again, PCE also had the CD add-on and Turbo Duo, which did better.
All in all, I guess Sega's arcade titles didn't really mean that much in Japan. What people wanted was Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy, and they continued buying the console that gave it to them until mid 2000s. Also, Nintendo was still strong after the success of the Famicom, and basically the competition had no chance going toe to toe with them.

that's the problem, for MD there's very little info, and all of it is in Japanese. however, often these lists come from some valid statistic sources, like Famitsu or Media Create or other research companies, then never get credited as Japanese web is often like your Geocities pages. even if some of the lists are slightly inaccurate, they generally show about same general picture, with maybe some games go 1-2 positions higher or lower, or maybe slightly smaller / higher sales overall. The reason for this can be that they could have been compiled at different times and/or using different methodology (sales vs shipped games).
seeing 2 different lists showing about the same picture (2 first posts) looks convincing, and https://sites.google.com/site/gamedatalibrary/game-search?authuser=0 has incomplete data with lower numbers (later years of MD perhaps, as they don't have games made before '92 in there), but generally showing about same games in top 10, top 20, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9496158
Japan cared more about Square / Enix, and way less so about arcade action, so SFC dominated there. But in the West, they cared way more about action, sports and mascot platformers, so one of Nintendo's biggest advantages meant very little there.
Also note that almost all of the best-selling SFC games in Japan were exclusives (save for a few like Street Fighter 2 or Puyo Puyo). But in the West, again due to popularity of the sports and cartoon games, a lot of the biggest sellers were multiplats. Mortal Kombat, NFL / NBA Jam, Aladdin, Lion King etc. came out on both platforms. So again, the gap narrowed hard. Genesis getting a lot of Western developer titles also didn't help.
And yes, Sega's marketing and Ninty's kiddy image in the West could've hurt too, but it's hard to say how much.
Regardless, data may vary, but according to NPD, Genesis was often beating SNES (albeit not by much) until late '94. It took DKC for Nintendo to truly give an answer to Sega. (see https://www.sega-16.com/forum/showthread.php?26110-January-December-1994-NPD-sales-data! ).

>>9496068
>I refuse to believe anyone has beaten Needle Man without cheating
I assume you are just another moron who just randomly shoots and jumps as soon he enters into the RM's rooms instead of paying attention to their individual attack patterns.

Once you enter into Needle Man's room, his attack pattern will be triggered as soon you attack him OR if you don't do anything for a few seconds. His attack pattern consists of jumping and sending a barrage of needles once he reaches his highest point, and once he lands, he will either shoot more needles OR headbutt you depending of how far or near of him you are.
To avoid his air attacks you only need to let him shoot his first 2 needles before you make a high jump to force him to shoot his next ones over your head so you could safely shoot at him before he lands. Jump or slide away to stay outside of his headbutt attack so you could force him to just fire his normal needles, which are easy to dodge and leave him open to a counterattack.
If you stay outside of his headbutt range and do nothing you will trigger his normal jump battle routine again, preventing him from jumping to you to try to hit you or get close enough to use his headbutt attack.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9493708
>I think this might be the kicker if anything. Banjo doesn't really have anything in his arsenal that really gives a burst of speed or acts as a movement combo tool.
There's a post right before yours that talks about the main speedrunning technique for going fast. Rolls give banjo acceleration. You then jump mid roll to shoot a decent chunk further and to stop the slowdown from the roll. Speedrunners also have a technique to cycle between the two continuously. That, and there also triple jump tricks to stay in the air longer, where Banjo moves quicker than on the ground. The talon trot is actually not the best speed technique even though it looks like it. Also, people don't realize there are techniques used to climb and scale vertical platforms, which all involve precision jumping. The people who say there aren't any interesting alternative routes in the game or there aren't any platforming challenges should look into those.

It's not that fans expected more of the same and got something totally different. Rare literally promised more of the same and we got something totally different. At the time, there was a forum where rare gave updates about the game directly to fans. There was an official trailer for Banjo Kazooie 3. For whatever reason the game was scrapped and Banjo was put in a totally different game and most fans hated what they were seeing as soon as they said the game was moving in a different direction. I'm pointing this out because there's a common notion now that N&B was a decent game but everybody looked down on it because it was experimental and the fans didn't want it to be, but few people mention that there was originally a more traditional BK3 announced that was scrapped and replaced by N&B, and that's why the fans hated it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9491589
4 and 5 are great, 3 is pretty good, but 12 is legitimately excellent and having just played it recently I think it's a real shame its quality gets overshadowed by >Kris. From my notes:

Played on Maniac-Classic (H2 out of H4), on a fresh file - AKA no wifi content or full reclassing unlocked.
Started right off the back of replaying shadow dragon on H5... and holy FUCK am I glad I didn't select Lunatic difficulty instead. This mother fucker is HARD; I actually encountered multiple instances where finishing a chapter left me too mentally wiped to continue.

Anyway. I'm giving this an 8/10, but understand that it's generally actually a very solid 9/10; it's just that there's some bits of it that are so god damn rigid it's like you're playing advance wars instead. Incessant sets of same-turn reinforcements in near every other map that dump like 6 promoted units on you with such sheer damage output even your power fighters can't last more than one attack; a massive 8-chapter prologue that's so claustrophobic in size and so stringent in its expectations that you simply can't beat it without resetting each chapter 20 times over to get an exact read on how the AI behaves; enemy mobilization flags triggered by arbitrary obfuscated lines in the sand at the best of times, paired with maps so devilishly designed in their overlapping cross-crossing archer and mage ranges that even the most overpowered squad of fliers I've ever seen in a FE title get put in their place... it's a fucking lot, and you ALWAYS feel the pressure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491883
On the one hand, it's one of the most tightly crafted games I've ever seen, and particularly impressive coming off of Shadow Dragon's general careless smattering of cavaliers and knights to wing spear across a map; on the other, I don't think I've ever felt so much sheer contempt for the player in a first-party release, and it'd take a lot to convince me to go back anytime soon. And that's not even the extent of it, either; from the hole in your wallet that never once gets plugged, to the Arenas so backloaded and so rigged against you entering one is like having a dev spit directly in your eye, to an endgame that had me get trapped in a corner for half an unironic hour as I was forced to desperately dig myself out from under an avalanche of *50* fully fledged stat capped god damn dragons, there's just nothin' else like it.

And honestly? I didn't even fuckin' care about Chris. They're just a blank slate for the other characters to bounce off of, wholly inconsequential. Plus, their presence allows for a good hundred+ actual support conversations and a whole sideplot added alongside in 5 uniquely designed gaiden chapters; yeah, their hat-wearing antics are dumb, but it's an inconsequential sort of dumb. And in fact, all that content they bring - combined with the Fire Emblem BS remake content included and the sheer replayability afforded by having your nuts kicked in in with new and exciting intensity - has me honestly convinced this might be one of the most content-rich FE games out there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491895
That's 'bout it, I figure. If I *do* ever come back for lunatic, though - some notes for me.
-EXP is PLENTIFUL; by endgame you'll be forced to kill enemies with 20/20 units for lack of worthwhile trainees. Don't get obsessed.
-Money is SCARCE; if you want to arena abuse though, do it with multiple characters 5-6 times each. There's an obfuscated cap on how much it'll let you do; after x number of battles it'll secretly up the enemy scaling, until after ~10 wins or so you'll ONLY be matched with impossible battles against 0-damage generals, dracos and paladins. It'll be even worse on lunatic I'm sure - honestly best to ignore in full if you can manage, trying to brute force it ruined a good few days of my life.
-The game gives you plenty of vulns and basic weapons; don't buy any of the former, and be conservative with the latter...
-But even still, DO FORGE; you DO NOT NEED wing spears or armorslayers in this game, but a might/hitforged Dracospear'll do you good.
-And LOOK UP SPAWN LOCATIONS, TOO; for real, Anri's way and its 12-move wyvern spawns are asinine, and that moment in chapter 19 where approaching the seize zone causes 12 promoted paladins and horsemen to simultaneously spawn in a perfect circle around you is so awful it's comical.
-Make sure to keep at least ~2-3 rescue staff uses + the same number of renew uses for the last chapter; you get a second hammerne in the penultimate chapter, and WILL want to use it...
-And finally - if you want to raise alt characters (Est), reclassing to cleric honestly isn't a bad way to go. They'll keep most of the STR growth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491589
They're all worth playing out of curiosity because they're all fairly different, but not all of them are good.

First one feels barebones as expected, even if it has a decent amount of stuff for its time, and is extremely slow with annoying inventory management, but if you want to see how the series started, why not. Some broken stuff is fun to abuse.

Second one has trash maps, but at least it's different. idk, just give it a try and see if you like it, but I personally think it's average. Feels closer to a JRPG than to an actual SPRG.

Third one includes a remake of the first one which is more fun than the original imo. The new part is solid even if some early maps are a bit of a slog. Also has two of the best pegasus riders in the series which makes it very fun.

Fourth game is considered by some to be the best in the series and has a lot of unique stuff, though the huge maps can be an issue for some people. It's really an epic adventure worth playing at least once, and the best story in the franchise. Second best after Thracia imo.

Fifth one is my personal favorite and considered one of the best, it's fun as fuck with tons of cool mechanics, weapons and staves to use. Probably the best map design in the franchise too.

Sixth one is the first one made after Kaga, the creator of the series, left, and it shows. Barebones compared to the previous two. I actually prefer it to the other two GBA games because it's harder, but some maps can be tedious. Some get filtered by the low accuracy of your attacks but it's fine.

Also, play Tear Ring Saga and Berwick Saga, the games made by Kaga after he left IS. TRS is pretty much a FE game and it's better than most of the series, and BS is a contender for the title of best SPRG ever made imo, it's a masterpiece.

So if you're in a hurry, only play Genealogy, Thracia, TRS and BS, because they're very good. Then Mystery if you want more, and the first two games if you're curious, but don't expect much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
4 is defintely worth playing, as its story ambitions and scope remains impressive to this day; However, I do feel Kagafags tend to give its gameplay an unfair pass when its frankly not very interesting. I applaud its experimentation and innovation; FE was still in a phase of figuring out just what kind of game it was; but a lot of mechanics in FE4 end up completely redundant or underused to the point you wonder why they are even there. The game hands you units in the very the first map that are capable of soloing the game for you, and it continues to do this over the course of the game. The maps are filled with enormous swathes of empty spaces where nothing happens. Guarding your castle may as well not exist as a mechanic for how little it actually comes into play. Foot soldiers are hilariously gimped compared to horse units and don't get nearly enough firepower to make up for the disrepancy or inconveniance of their low movement speed. There's very little real challenge going on with the AI; The tried and true "bait an enemy with your toughest unit" strategy still works 99% of the time.

Its unfortunate, but FE4 biggest problem is that outside of its stellar presentation and plot, the game itself is kind of a boring slog. Its hard to justify playing it more than once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I played the PS1 game when I was like... 7 years old, and I really liked building my robot. That stuff was really compelling. The customisation is the real meat on the bones of this game, which is fortunate because the gameplay itself was pretty weak. But in fairness, I can't criticise it too harshly for that, it's only like when you play a mediocre RPG because you still get that nice dopamine hit from getting sweet loot.

To me, a real mech game should have a cockpit view and obtuse controls that make you really feel like you're a PILOT, not just that you're playing as a sentient robot. If they can pull off something that feels a bit more realistic and less weeby, I might be more interested.

But yeah, I think there are a lot of hipsters who claim the game is better than it is because it's FromSoft, much like with King's Field. I find it funny because they act like FromSoft have always had this enlightened genius game design when in reality, like most successes, Dark Souls was just kind of a lucky experimental combination of the right ingredients.

posts.com: it seems a faux pas to say, but i think RE4 really is the best horror game. it has a lot of action and 80s tier one-liners, but it's easy to forget about some of the legitimately creepy moments. as a kid, i always ran through the village at night when you first get ashley because of how scary it was; being in this pitch black, rainy farmland with a bunch of demented spaniards lurking in the dark is pretty unsettling. that's to say nothing of the first time you see regenerators, or even stranger shit like the bag in the dumpster that convulses. the way the game uses music to build atmosphere is fantastic too -- e.g., the merchant theme which is calm and protective but always serves as a warning of something sinister to come. the game's ability to create a sense of claustrophobia and dread is frankly amazing.

posts.com: I've been getting into this genre the past few months and one aspect of this genre that really surprised me was the realization of just how small it really was. There's a million RE games, a handful of SH games that actually matter, and then a lot of one off shit that either never caught on or was based on an some IP at the time. RE has definitely cemented itself as a pop culture icon, so why did the actual survival horror genre die so quickly exactly? By seventh gen it was all but dead, with only a mild resurgence in recent years. Perhaps it's part of an appeal to the genre but so many other games in this genre generally feel more along the lines of "passion projects" with a number of apparent flaws that would turn off average consumers, only RE and SH really feel like true "big budget" experiences. I was only born in 98 but to anyone that grew up with it just how long did RE stay relevant? It feels like RE2 was definitely still fresh in the minds of people but by RE3 it seems like there was a decline in interest overall.

This is a great question, and I'll try to answer it from my own point of view. Personally, I feel that the only games that have ever tried to imitate Resident Evil are its own series, and Dino Crisis 1. This is even debatable, as truthfully the only REAL survival horror games, as in games that both combine survival AND horror, without going down the more action heavy route, are RE1, REmake, and Dino Crisis.

Back to the subject though, you'll notice all of REs knock-offs barely ever tried to imitate its style. Even Silent Hill, its greatest rip-off, is absolutely nothing like Resident Evil. It has virtually no item management, and ammo is not scarce at all. Most of the games just try to rip off its camera angle and let you shoot monsters. But how many tried to copy the Mansion, or added in interesting, well-thought backtracking? How many are actually scarce on ammunition, or force you to really strategize how you go through each room? It just doesn't exist. I'm not sure if Resident Evil was just that good, or the developers were just flat out lazy and all of the clones were cash grabs. But they aren't very good in comparison, and they all lack polish.

>>9488479
I think SH3's strengths get overshadowed i general. It's a weird game in the series, it acts as a continuation of SH1's plot while telling a more personal narrative about Heather like SH2, making it feel "redundant" in ways. SH3 both tries to tell a deeper narrative happening around the protagonist and those around her but also have her experience her own personal journey, it's a very ambitious narrative that, overall, I would say works out well but doesn't feel quite as cohesive as the prior two entries. Generally I think people see SH3 as having "less meaning" in what the game, and this is true in a few regards but still pretty inaccurate to the overall. Honestly I think the symbolism and themes go over people's heads because they're so heavily based in the feminine experience. If you're a guy I feel like it's likely you just kind of don't think about things like the game's various menstrual imagery, though some things like the hole leading to the final boss are hard to miss.

I always have a hard time deciding between SH1 and SH3 as my personal favorite. SH3 has a lot going for it with the most refined gameplay and graphics of the series, but it's also the most obviously compromised of the first three games. The game has essentially no exploration outside of the dungeons and a handful of "grab thing, walk a room over, use thing" moments. It's a great game on its own merits, but how it compares to prior entries and their strengths gives a lot of differing thoughts. I would say that, as simply a "video game", that SH3 is the best, as to be expected being the newest, but it's clear pure gameplay is not why people love horror games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9494556
Emulation is fine, but make sure you can see the post processing effects otherwise you'll lose out on the panic "meter" (it's the whole screen), lighting, and reflections. Software mode works 100%, but I think one of the hardware modes works now if your computer can handle it. Use this timestamp in this video as a reference for what I'm describing.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ektkbejc-sE#t=11m37s

Notice how the screen turns more black&white, and slightly blurry when her heart beats, as Fiona inspects the blood? That's her panicking. The effect gets more pronounced the more she panics, until she loses it. It's important to the gameplay so you understand when you need to calm down.

Just beat both SH2 and SH3 for the first time ever this week. Really loved and enjoyed both, and upset that I didn't play either much sooner. >>9482789
>>9482861
If I could add, I'd say the biggest issue SH3 had was the pacing. Everything from the beginning in the mall through to when you reach Heather's apartment felt like one extremely drawn out introductory section. I realize the mall alone is supposed to be that, but you go straight from the mall to the subway, then straight to the sewers, then straight to the construction yard, and then the office building, all with no interruption, story elements or anything to essentially let the player "catch their breath". You get one minor moment with Vincent in the office, and then that's it until the apartments. And by that point? You basically hit the halfway mark of the game, you get the big reveal immediately, and then everything kicks into overdrive as you finally get to Silent Hill itself. SH3 really could have used more time to pace out its story and have moments where players could "rest", especially in the first half.

The 700 and 900 series has a fucked up frame buffer that completely breaks v-sync for applications that use BitBlt, so all windowed applications, and many fullscreen apps to.

I am not entirely sure what exact is going on, but its possible that the frame buffer the card presents to windows is not the true hardware frame buffer, and some kind of dma copy is triggered on retrace, either way the frame buffer is really screwy.

The problem with overclocking the original Star Fox is how the game is tied to the framerate. the game music is timed to the games crap framjerate. For example, Star Fox on real hardware:

(note how the intro cut sscene ends at the right music cue)

30fps overclock:

Polygon cutscene ends way before the music ends. The devs designed Star Fox around its awful framerate. In order to make Star Fox look right at 60fps, the game would have to be modified to match the timing of the new framerate. posts.com:
Why hasn't anyone ever attempted to port Snatcher to the SEGA 32X CD?
The SEGA CD version is great, especially with the added light gun support that the PC Engine CD version lacked.
However, the SEGA CD version has much less colours and has been graphically downgraded compared to the PC Engine CD version because the Genesis can output much less colours at a time compared to the PC Engine.
There's also the issue of minor censorship in the SEGA CD version.

Restoring the uncensored content is one thing, but it would be much harder to restore the higher colour depth of the PC Engine CD to the SEGA CD without having to port it to the 32X.

The SEGA CD version has many changes from the PC Engine CD version. Even the soundtrack is different.
Also, there's no light guns for the PC Engine, but the SEGA Genesis does.

The Genesis version is a mostly superior version of Snatcher, aside from the lower colour depth and some censorship.
It's also impossible to do a fan translation of the PC Engine CD version unless you can somehow hack the game to have properly synced English subtitles.
The SEGA CD version was specifically made to give the game an international English release.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9491513
The 9801 can do 640x400 with 16 colors and a blitter or 256 color packed pixel (for the 9821 models) at the same resolution, and especially that fucking sound chip. Earlier sound cards and Epson machines have a YM2203 (3 FM and 3 PSG channels), later machines/cards have the YM2608 (6 FM, 3 PSG, PCM) and the cost reduced YMF288. To add to that, there's the fact a lot of PC-98 game composers did not have the same styles nor influences as other FM composers.
https://youtu.be/FMKA3UFgINY
https://youtu.be/EJ9mfjn1Ry0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pV1DbMjWuFE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ONCcQjgvE2s

The 9801VM, VX, and newer are like a Tandy 1000 in the sense it's an "enhanced DOS" computer, but it's incompatible with normal MS-DOS stuff. It also has a more powerful CPU than the FM Towns (socket 3 and 5 models of that are rare or overpriced), is extremely cheap (shipping costs more, I got the Pentium Pro one for $20), and the sprite art is distinct to the point there's a Twitter bot (@PC98_bot) dedicated to posting PC-98 screencaps. Put it this way, a V30 or 286 can run games that need a 386 in the PC Compatible world to run, and to make things more interesting there were games from 1996 that could run on a V30 (basically an 8086). No really, YU-NO and other VNs will run on anything but the original 9801/E/F/M.

Most models also have a BASIC interpreter in the ROM that's pretty powerful for a 1980s BASIC interpreter. Even my Pentium Pro model has it, but my 9821Nr15 lacks it. It's a technically interesting computer that's also really cheap.

>>9496680
Use this wiki for information on emulators
https://emulation.gametechwiki.com/index.php/Main_Page
And this page has safe links to rom sets on archive.org
https://r-roms.github.io/

For PS1 the best and easiest to use emu is Duckstation
https://www.duckstation.org/
And for the game I recommend getting the .chd for lower file size. It's in here
https://archive.org/download/chd_psx/CHD-PSX-USA/

If you're willing to emulate, you could also go directly for the arcade version. Though I found that it had hyper sensitive controls when I tried it. But you'll have to use MAME, which isn't as accessible (FinalBurn Neo is an easier arcade emulator, but it doesn't support Pole Position)
https://www.mamedev.org/
I get MAME roms from torrents listed on this site here:
https://pleasuredome.github.io/pleasuredome/mame/index.html
Scroll down to "MAME full sets" and get the "non-merged" set, that one is most convenient because all required files will be included with each rom.
Of course uncheck all the files in your torrent client, you don't want the whole massive set, just check the rom you want.
MAME uses special filenames for each rom, to find out what it is, look up a game using this database:
http://adb.arcadeitalia.net/
In this case, the filename for Pole Position is "polepos". There is other helpful information on the page, including required files (but you shouldn't have to worry about that if you got the non-merged rom from pleasuredome).
http://adb.arcadeitalia.net/dettaglio_mame.php?game_name=polepos&arcade_only=0&autosearch=1

If that all seems too complicated, just go for the PS1 collection instead, it's probably fine.

Okay so the way the powerups work is that each colour is a different type of attack. To upgrade them you need to collect the same colour repeatedly without collecting the other colours, otherwise you go back to the lv1 version of the collected weapon. Try it, it will make a huge difference. Melee enemies that get close because itll either oneshot them or knock them back giving you room for a charge shot. They have very basic patterns to play around once you know how they work. Boss of stage 1 is a bit of a pain if you dont know the patterns and some require you get into position before the attack comes out. If the turret is spinning one way try to be one the end of that rotation so you have enough time to read the pattern before youre expected to dodge. Shifting levels and ducking is effective. You can do it!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464565
Prototyping ASICs. That's basically the reason they were invented.
Aviation and automation. It's cheaper in the long run to run the onboard software on an FPGA simulated ASIC than an actual ASIC because when some new bullshit law comes in that demands your component respond 0.0001% faster you can just update the hardware with new HDL at a routine service, rather than expensive downtime at a factory where somebody has to literally take it apart and solder a new chip on, and you don't have an expensive new ASIC run to produce.
Military. Same deal. Any hardware flaws can be fixed in the field, you don't have to say "sorry Vlad, can we postpone the war, we're upgrading our nukes to Ryzen."

>>9467459
>I'm still not sure what this thing is
You're familiar with the term FPGA, in a loose fashion, yeah? MiSTer is a project that is taking advantage of a cheap FPGA that people can buy, called the DE-10 Nano. The DE-10 Nano is cheap because it is made for college students, and is subsidized by Intel. The DE-10 Nano has an FGPA on board, as well as an ARM chip. It has various connectors on the board for expandability. MiSTer has a bunch of FPGA cores (much like the cores you would see on one of the Analog systems) for consoles, handhelds, arcade boards and computers. Developers are constantly adding more cores and improving on existing cores. A hobbiest community has popped up around this project, which has led to a lot of hardware addons that can be installed onto the DE-10 Nano, such as extra RAM, a digital or analog I/O board, USB hub (these things make up the most common MiSTer setup that you have likely seen, which is a sandwich of three boards with the DE-10 Nano in the middle)... etc. There are people who have made specialized expansion boards like the MiSTercade, which allows it to be used in a typical JAMMA arcade cabinet. At a base level, you really just need the DE-10 Nano, and preferably a RAM stick, the rest is optional.

MiSTer can be appealing to enthusiasts because it offers better accuracy/latency compared to software emulation. It's also very easy to set up and use in a variety of scenarios, without having to invest in a bunch of extra shit like flash carts, upscalers, custom cables... etc. It is an all-in-one solution for many of the systems that a retro gamer would be interested in. By its nature, it is also very customizable.

I still think that software emulation is a good option, especially on a budget since you can probably do it on hardware that you already own, however I do like my MiSTer quite a bit and I find that I am playing more /vr/ games than ever since getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the perfect middle ground. You've got original hardware accurate latency, perfect audio timing, ease of use with a CRT and compatibility with a number of peripherals, tied with loading roms, save states for some cores, using any controller you want, and emulation perks like CPU overclocking for SNES.

If you're into collecting and playing carts, then go real hardware. But if you were just going to buy flash carts for all of your systems, I don't see any reason not to just go the mister route. You're getting the same console quality experience. And you don't have to worry about shit like HDMI mods for your hardware, or upscalers like the retrotink if you want to hook it up to a modern TV, it has all that built in. You don't have to worry about RGB modding hardware to get the most clarity, it's all just built in.

I think it's a really nifty option and I have no clue why /vr/ shits themselves over it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464069
Runahead latency isn't accurate. FPGA is latency accurate, in that a good core can reasonably achieve identical latency to original hardware.

Additionally the overhead to achieve accurate latency is much easier. Software emulators generally try for timing accuracy or cycle accuracy with a lot of optimization and tricks required to do so. With FPGA once you've defined the logic it mostly just works how you'd expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464110
With FPGA the actual video circuit of the recreated system directly drives the raster of the CRT, just like the original hardware could. You will always have a framebuffer on PC, always some abstraction away from native interf
aces.

>lol. no. The whole purpose of AOM is to develop open free codecs
Yeah, of course, and I support it very much and am happy we have dedicated hardware for it now but in the context of what I am talking about, it is a whole lot easier to sell FPGA software for new capabilities than an entirely new chip that will have costs in the hundreds of millions to over a billion to make.
>I don't even know what "putting in ASICs in chips" is supposed to mean, but the last part really highlights your logic fail. If something's not going to sell enough to justify the redesign to do it more efficiently, faster, smaller, cheaper, then how will you even justify the redesign to do it less efficiently, slower, larger and more expensive?
If you are going to feign ignorance, try harder. But in any case, if you want to create a dedicated circuit for functionality and integrated in a chip over putting it on an FPGA for a customer, that may very well work today and is what all chipmakers do. But I am saying it won't work in the future with rising costs per node. And the redesign is for flexibility in mind, which will win out over efficiency, speed and size because of cost which will be the main driver of chipmaking in the future. And it's not like you can't deliver more cutting edge than 28nm products because costs are too expensive there too. The newest FPGA line from Lattice announced last week is using TSMC 16nm and they are one of the cheapest providers in the market. It's just not going to be as cutting edge as the other chiplets on the package if it is integrated into a common CPU combo.

I don't want to keep driving the topic on /vr/ off course when we have devolved into a /g/ discussion so I'm going to stop replying regardless of your response but I just fundamentally think that we can't go into the end of scaling transistors down without involving FPGAs into a common consumer usecase whether it's a conscious decision on their part or the manufacturer.

2/2
