posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Welcome to the Gauntlet!
Normally you would randomly choose games from full lists and see if you can beat them in 3 days, and that lead to the Gauntlet just kinda dying off here and everywhere else really. So how about we try something different this time around? Instead of randomly picking games for a bunch of platforms, YOU pick out your games. But there's a catch. We aren't doing every platform at once back-to-back, and you can do multiple games from the same platform over the course of the Gauntlet if this survives. We're also going chronologically starting from 1985.
You pick one console released that year or prior to it, and one computer platform, or and one handheld(this really won't be a part of it unless we reach 1989), or arcade games. Either way, you pick out two platforms to choose from. Then you choose one game released on each platform that year or any time prior, and have one week to get a clear/high score to post for both games chosen. Screenshots aren't the only thing encouraged, tell us why you picked that game. Tell us about the game. If you know how to make webm's of your gameplay, post those. I'll gladly help anyone who needs help getting a game to run in MAME for the Gauntlet. If the thread is still alive by next week, we go on to 1986. Otherwise I'll figure this isn't a workable fix for the Gauntlet and let it die. It's either this, curated lists, or death.
You won't play a crap game unless you choose to. You also have two games to switch between to prevent burnout. You can use any website you want to search for and choose the games you want to play instead of needing a list picker. If you want a challenge, you can pick hard games. If you want to try new things, you can do that. If you want to stick with games you enjoy, go for it.
Anyone interested in playing and posting about retro videogames?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's not as popular now as it used to be, but it's still alive. Every version has at least one private server.

Most populated servers for each version:
Dreamcast: Sylverant https://sylverant.net
Gamecube: Schthack https://schtserv.com
Xbox: Schthack https://schtserv.com
PC: Ephinea https://ephinea.pioneer2.net

Gamecube and Xbox are similar enough to crossplay, and they just got it working mere weeks ago. But Dreamcast and PC versions are too different from the others for crossplay to work.

PC is the most popular version these days, and in some ways the best one, as it's the only one with Episode 4.

If you want to play on a console, I'd recommend the Gamecube version on a Wii. Dreamcast is missing Episode 2. Getting ethernet hardware for either Dreamcast or Gamecube is expensive. Cheaper on an Xbox obviously, but that's still a little glitchy - I see Xbox players disconnecting a lot.

Wii is cheap and easy to hack (https://wii.guide), only requires a USB adapter for ethernet, which you can find for $10 on Ebay (although make sure you get the right one). Once you have that, the homebrew app Nintendont will load the game and emulate the Broadband Adapter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473260
Absolutely. Especially if you can get friends in on the splitscreen multiplayer. One of the things that impressed me most about PSO on GCN is that everyone can have their own characters on their own memory cards, and are completely independent. If you start a party with friends in FF Crystal Chronicles, your character is stuck in that party. In PSO though, you can play with one group of friends one day, and then take your memory card and use the same character with a completely different group of friends the next day. 4 players can play together with 4 different characters on 4 different memory cards, even though the gamecube only has 2 memory card ports.

One caveat though; the camera sucks in split screen. Don't jump straight into multiplayer with four level 1 characters. Everyone should play a bit of single player first to get used to playing the game before their screen gets shrunk down to one-quarter of the screen. And to get some money for restocking healing items.

>Interviewer: Obviously, Diablo was a big influence on PSO. How much of Diablo did you play yourself?
>I played quite a lot. Nobody on our team had worked on an online game, so one of the challenges was getting the team to understand what made online games fun. I had a lot of people play the game, but a lot of them were turned off by the dark fantasy. They would say, “it’s disturbing,” or, “I don’t get why it’s fun.” Trying to unify the team and getting them to understand the direction we wanted to take the game in was very difficult.

>Interviewer: Did you have LAN parties, where you played in a controlled environment so that the team could understand the cooperative elements?
>We installed Diablo on everyone’s PC in the office and had a closed LAN and spent many days playing together so that the team could learn what network gaming was all about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473764
>Interviewer: Was there a point where you saw people starting to get the appeal, like the satisfaction of seeing a rare item drop, where you felt the team really get into the game?
>Some people like Setsumasa stayed around until 10 or 11 p.m. at night after people left the office. He would connect Diablo to the network and play until morning, wake up to work, and then play again. Some of us weren’t going home much at the time. Some people would go home just to bathe, sleep a few hours, come back into the office to work, and then play Diablo at the office. It was mostly in the name of research, though. There are a number of games that we used as inspiration. Diablo was obviously one of them. I had heard that Dragon Quest was inspired by remaking Ultima with a Japanese audience in mind. So our concept was, “Let’s make a Diablo game that would appeal to the Japanese audience.”

>Interviewer: With good results. Even though Diablo is a distinctly American game, PSO feels like a very distinctly Japanese game. And yet, it’s not just palatable to Japanese gamers but to everyone.
>I think Diablo is an amazing game, but it’s not a game that appeals to Japanese players. Our suspicion was that Japanese gamers would prefer to cooperate and work together to defeat something more than to compete and fight against other players. That’s why we created PSO to be a cooperative role-playing game. Diablo has cooperative elements but it also has PK and an element of killing other player characters. We eliminated those elements and focused on how we could make a fun, cooperative RPG experience. I think that’s the biggest difference between PSO and Diablo.

I remember playing on my own after, and making it easily through the next area, but I didn't have experience with these types of games, nor did I really get the whole dungeon-looting loop since I had mostly played linear games that didn't require grinding before that. I fell off, sadly, but I'll always appreciate the atmosphere this series set up with its cool designs, great music, etc. I gave PSU a shot when that came out, I think in a demo version, and it somehow landed with me more than PSO did at the time, but I think it's just simply because I wasn't as stupid with game genres anymore. >>9471103
Why is the FOnewearl circled in your image?

I remember I really didn't like it at first in its day. I thought it was a simplified Diablo styled generated item gathering loop with less fluid combat that I was unimpressed with just based on watching it played solo at a friend's place. However so many of my friends were playing and they wanted me to play alongside them, so they gave me their Japanese copy (since they went online with the US version) since I couldn't afford the game. My friends even chipped in to buy the Dreamcast keyboard for me as a Christmas gift, as they couldn't stand the wait for me to d-pad type messages. The mechanics are simplistic, but then meeting so many and finding out others I knew outside my main circles of friends were playing, made it an amazing communal experience. Even met a few others through the game joining randoms and enjoyed the whole vibe of playing alongside others. The people playing were very friendly and even though the translations were all scuffed using the chat preset phrases, some very diverse teams were made on the fly. The music and visuals were fantastic and are embedded into my memories, so in the end I love the game more for the whole time with it than the game itself. Alas, it is an experience tied to the time it was out, and I am so glad I was there for it.

posts.com:
Thread for introducing anon's to classic point & click adventure games.

>What qualifies as a classic point & click adventure game?
Games which are first person or isometric, which require movement or progression from using a pointer to advance, pick up objects, and/or solve puzzles. They can be 2D sprites, FMV, or 3D.

>POINT OF THIS THREAD
If you are a P&C virgin, or are somewhat new to P&C games, or simply don't care but would be interested in exploring more of them, this thread is for you. Just ask for recc's for anything in particular.

>RESOURCES
UNIVERSAL HINT SYSTEM - If you are forced cheat and look up the solutions to puzzles, do it through this website. It does not give you the answer to puzzles outright, instead opting to give you more and more detailed hints, and has virtually every single classic, as well as many new, P&C games.
https://www.uhs-hints.com/

ADVENTURE GAME DATABASE - Has nearly every single adventure game you could possibly think of, with the genre's they belong to, screenshots, availability, platforms, development info, and a summary of the game.
https://www.adventuregamedb.com

DEAD END GUIDES - Websites which blatantly state all the known dead-end states in the most well-known Sierra franchises.

>>9490850
>That should be the one thing Point and Click games should have going for them in exchange for 0 action.
Where to start, where to start...
1 - No, it isn't, why would time and events matter at all if there is "zero action"? The most someone would expect from a game with zero action should be characters, then story, then plot, then animation, then world-building.

2 - Puzzle solving is action. Not all action needs to be combat based with megaman-esque "SHOOT THE THING TILL IT DIES!" or Ninja Gaiden-esque "SLASH THE THING TILL IT DIES!" gameplay, you zoomer.

3 - I have no idea what you're talking about in regards to point and click games having "Zero action". Even if you don't include puzzle solving, for some bizarre reason, there's still plentiful examples, such as the Quest for Glory games, the Conquests games, the Indiana Jones games, Even in games with no combat mechanics, you still directly and indirectly "fight" various enemies, such as in King's Quest 1 where you fight/defeat a Giant (which you defeat with a slingshot), a Dragon (which you defeat with a bucket of water), a Troll (which you defeat with a goat), and a Witch (which you push into a boiling cauldron), and there's examples like this in most point and click games.

But even still, going back to your original point, Quest For Glory 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 all have a consistent time-based events system. The Colonel's Bequest is another one, along with Conquests of the Longbow. Even Secret of Monkey Island has combat in it.

I'm just stating the facts. PCSX2 is pretty much the fastest and most accurate it's been in years due to various changes that have occurred throughout the past 1-2 years. If you can't run the game on Vulkan now, then no previous version of PCSX2 is going to let you magically run it at full speed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's simple. Some people had it as kids and it gives them a great nostalgia.

Consider this: I never had a PS1, but I had a PS2, so I did have access to PS1 but I only had like 5 PS1 games total, and they were kinda all bad. However, I did buy lots of PS1 magazines. (yes they were still making PS1 magazines in 01-03). Those magazines had demos in it. So I got to play lots of demos and I was 100% invested in the PS1 scene and its many titles.... even though I had never really played any of them. I ended up having lots of PS2 games but I never saw the PS2 as being as good as the PS1. It's just difficult to explain, despite not having hands-on experience with practically any PS1 games, there is still something incredibly soulful about PS1 that PS2 never reached. I bought and played tons of PS2 games and I only played the odd PS1 game through emulator or something but I still preferred PS1.
The point is, it doesn't matter how many games Dreamcast had, for some people it encapsulates a certain moment in time, a certain mantra. I think Dreamcast is meh but I think I can understand this pov since I have a similar relationship with PS1

Yes.

Some GREAT fucking ST games. They are not all exclusives, but the ST versions often have their own charm:

Time Bandits https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VrvIgbsEG-A&list=PLD7CEB7FCED6C99EC&ab_channel=Chelseacf
Mudpies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8u5uMS50qNc&ab_channel=Steve%5BAtariCrypt%5D
Sun Dog https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kg_hEY_hy9U&ab_channel=Wasabim
Major Motion https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bASGBe6jhes&ab_channel=Nival
Bratacas https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PRWzrKvqnKs&t=93s&ab_channel=W.D.Callahan
Hacker https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SHrLhk5StY&t=379s
Hacker 2 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mOgkET76VTE&t=244s

Those are just the ones I had growing up. There are a lot more. Learn the emulator and get the roms from the pirate disks:
https://www.atarilegend.com/menusets

These are all pirate disks, you'll want to look up what's on them online, or in this site. Basically, back in the day, pirates would crack and compress games and put them into a single floppy image so people could pass around pirated games. Like, it was physical piracy. The sort of stuff you kids love to hear about. The only reason we have the ST catalog anymore is because of these pirates. Automation, Pompey Pirates, Zuul and the others. Some of these disks have viruses on them, but like... who cares? Harmless, and kinda cute!

People do still use these things for MIDI. The beat timing is PERFECT. You can't really get that perfect timing with a machine that parses time by the femtosecond. Like, a new PC just doesn't have that PERFECT beat timing, say some musicians. We could all debate this, just like we could debate vinyl versus digital, tubes versus circuits, etc.... There's a guy in LA who owns all these things and sells them for parts and replacements into the industry. I sold him pallettes of the things in the early 2000s. Shoulda charged him more.

Have fun, explore. There's a lot out there.

>>9490571
Its biggest selling point was the MIDI interface that was used in studio and hollywood productions. Had LOTS of great homebrew/shareware/independently published software packages, game experiments, and utilities. Most games were pretty close to the Amiga ports but I unfortunately have to admit a lot of big titles often ran better on the Amiga. However it was an exceptionally soulful machine and I think the much larger catalog made it work.

I don't know if anyone else will remember this, but there was a company called BRE Software that put out a periodic catalog where you could order floppy disks and they had just TONS AND TONS of random weird shit you could get, tools, programming samples, demo scene shit, ports of unix roguelikes, BBS software, etc etc. It was so great, what a wonderful wild west time in software development. Sadly the company ended up just becoming a generic Xbox/Playstation store after the 16-bit computer market died out.

>>9491037

One of the most interesting things about the design of these early systems is how much of it was dictacted by the timing to drive a TV display. That's why Mister FPGA is so important as it retains this end to end system design, where the raster beam is electronically part of the system.

Now display is a few separate mostly independent systems (CPU->GPU->display) just shovel some data over.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9494557

I tried playing this game through all the way to the end, and I can't decide if I like it or not. nThe first D is a Myst clone, but has a horror theme. It's one of those point and click FMV games. D2 tries to be a point and click FMV style game, but with real time polygons. The original D2 was being planned for the Panasonic M2 and was a completely different game. That one was scrapped and Warp started over with a new game for the Dreamcast. the game is set in some Canadian wasteland... NWT? IDK... and there are three game modes. One is the 'in-door' mode that plays 100% like a point and click mist game with real time polygons. There's the game map area, where you can run around freely a bit, and hunt for food, using a hunting system. There's the combat system that plays almost like a light gun game. Was this game meant to use a light gun? For point and click adventure games, Snatcher on the CD added a light gun and so did Policenauts on the PS1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The game tries to be a real time cinematic adventure game. It was impressive for a late 1999 game. Silent Hill 1 was released in early 1999 on the PS1. the game has survival horror elements too.

>>9471772
>I'm playing MRA2 as well. Do you have any tip for a first-timer?
Nothing really specific to this games campaign as I haven't really bothered with finding many secrets or anything, but some basic tips on raising monsters, you may already know all this but....

Always make sure you relieve monsters "stress" and "fatigue", always let it rest obviously but also use items like oil or mintcandy to remove fatigue after training and battles. Battling itself actually helps remove monsters stress. As you accumulate larger amounts of cash, it's definitely good to prioritize buying all the more expensive stress relieving, fatigue relieving, and sleep helping items you'll see in the shop like the cups and gems, as can afford them of course, don't skip out on them, they'll make it easier for new monsters. Also don't let your monster get fat or malnourished, fat monsters get fatigued more and underweight monsters get stressed more.

Also take it easy on baby monsters, just do the most basic training until its more mature aka when Holly tells gives you that cue that it's an "important time" or whatever she says, that's when you start the coach routines

Always focus on like 3, maybe 4 main stats to train your monster in. Having a balanced monster doesn't really work because there's only so much time you can put into training during its lifespan, you want your monster to excel hard in specific areas, not be average in many areas, so take that into consideration when deciding what monster you wanna raise and how you want it to grow/what moves you want it to learn

When you're stronger and start doing sparring with the intention of learning new moves specifically, it's not really worth it unless you're gonna learn a new move, so don't bother wasting the money and time unless it says there's a chance your monster will learn a new move, and honestly I say theres no shame in saving before and restarting until you learn the move

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They could have gone in a few different directions with Umbrella after '96

1. They could have made them an incompetent corporation dabbling with reduced research budgets that shits the bed and ruins an entire city/nation. Evidenced by Wesker being a little preening bitch/retard that thinks the Ultimate Lifeform has an exposed heart and could easily be dabbed on by a crew served weapons. Would have been an interesting take

2. They are hypercompetent psychopaths looking develop weapons to expand the war economy and/or depopulate earth. For the military theT-virus would be a great weapon to load into short range ballistic missiles and fire into the rear eschelon of your enemy. It would also be great to sew havoc on an over populated world while Umbrella chills out in the global south only to return as kings of a new order once the virus has burnt out. Capcom neither had the writing talent nor were franchises herded in a such a way until the advent of the Marvelverse

3. They are mustache twirling sadists that do evil shit for the sake of being evil, and reveling in it.

Capcom went with #3. RE2, RE3, CV all built the pillar of "Umbrella are too stupid to exist, but at least they are comically evil". Lisa Trevor fits in this slot. She also adds some pathos to the game much in the same was RE4 did with the ending credits (eg. no player, YOU are the monster).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9487747
Some of them do a lot of shit behind the curtains so they can be more authentic, breaking the image own into red, green and blue channels and combining them, applying halation, glow, blur, curvature, scanline shape, etc. all in separate passes, like stacking blocks building up the final image.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484149
I just wanted to post ITT because I loved playing E.V.O. when it came out. I thought it was a great game and the underwater world was my favorite.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cSu1dyra1oQ

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487747
If it was just an overlay of lines, it'd be nothing.
But a proper shader is separating red, green, and blue signals for each pixel into separate phosphors, applying distortion onto the overall image, specific blending properties based on adjacent colors, etc. And all of this has to be done to every pixel on every rendered frame.
On top of the game being played in the first place, it's a lot.

Yes, very much so. I think it was in a way a peak of vidya, when it reached highest potential and variety, with Japan being arguably at its peak, and when 2D wasn't yet pushed out by 3D; but before whole studios and whole genres started dying out due to huge budgets, before the "normieficiation" of vidya with GTA3 / Halo.
you can see how in >>9494313 there's plenty genres that heavily declined after that. fighters, horror, RTS & TBS, adventure, platformers, etc.
in other genres, games were still inventive (system shock 2, final fantasy 8, crazy taxi, etc.). and there were still weirdo / genre breaking games games like vib ribbon.
and you can see how crazy the legacy of some of those games is. there's steal a huge community for street fighter 3 3rd strike, heroes of might and magic iii, age of empires ii, quake 3 and more. they hold up without any "good for its time" excuses.

I would check out Psikyo games, such as Sonic Wings (Arcade), Sengoku Ace, Gunbird, Strikers 1945. You can also try out something like 1944 or 19XX. All of these have pretty simple systems, but are still very challenging games with some brutal patterns.

If you want something really simple, check out some of the PCE shooters, like the Soldier trilogy (Super Star Soldier, Final Soldier, Soldier Blade), Nexzr, Blazing Lazers, etc. Gate of Thunder is also excellent, although it's less beginner friendly.

>>9496891
Joust 2, obscure by the virtue that most people don't know there even was a sequel. It didn't do as well as the original, since it came out with graphics and sound on par with the original years later. Which is a shame, since the game can be considered an expert level challenge for pros of the first game. Similar concept and gameplay except now you can change between your fast flying ostrich and a slow but good in combat lion or dragon or something. Switching between the two effectively is the key to success, but very difficult to learn.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9496189
It's a blurry line between plagiarism, homage and inspiration. Warcraft's main influences are obviously Dungeons and Dragons(and by extension european folklore and tolkien) and Warhammer.

With your examples they aren't even straight up copies, the elven duality does come from high/dark elves but Nights Elves are not so much dark elves as they are wood elves and they added the moon worship bullshit which harkens back to Diana/Artemis from roman/greek mythology which was both the goddess of the moon and of the hunt/woods/nature and from there it was is to throw in more greek nature stuff like dryads and hippogryphs. But then you still have stuff like the tree of life which is norse and the Ancients(the living tree buildings) are just Tolkien Ents. So yeah the whole thing is just an hodge podge of tropes, most medieval fantasy is.

If you want the most obvious direct visual reference of all it would be the Beastmaster/Rexxar is a direct copy of Darkwolf from Fire and Ice

posts.com:
https://www.mediafire.com/file/1djiv2hajqr56z0/Sonic+XG+Leaks.7z/file

If you don't know what XG is:

Sonic eXtended Genesis, aka Sonic XG, is a game being created by Sir Euan and Nitemare, and has gone through many different variations in the past.

At one point in time, the fangame was going to be merged with Retro Sonic in 2007 and eventually Sonic Nexus in 2010 in order to create Retro Sonic Nexus, but is again being developed as a separate title, with a new team of devs.

This is mostly all of XG. You have builds and source code from 2007-2021, and a level called "Golden Gate" from possibly 2005 to 2007.

Anyway, have fun with XG!

By the way, multiple people are leaking this. Saw one guy on YouTube. You can spread this around if you want.

The image attached is me inserting the Golden Gate level layout into the 2007 source code. It kinda worked, but I need to change the background.

I also leaked this in spite of the new devteam, which are kinda toxic and evil and shit.

So yeah, have fun.

I don't know if this is due to localization, but I always found Kefka's characterization post-WoR to be a bit weird. For most of the game he's a gleeful, sadistic psychopath who delights in making others suffer before ultimately killing them. His willing, knowing destruction of the world aligns with this, even if it appears to have been done on a whim. Now he has ultimate power to make the world an utterly miserable place for everyone, and he can kill and destroy anything and anyone with but a thought. But when you go to face him, he starts with brooding nihilistic shit he never brought up before, about how clinging to life is stupid if people know they're ultimately gonna die, etc. Then your party gives their reasons for going on living, and the mask comes off and he's back to having fun with taking "precious lives", but not before stating his ultimate objective is to just outright destroy everything, which would leave him without purpose or lives to end for his amusement. So, what's his deal? Is he just so powerful in his insanity that he stopped giving a shit?

I don't like how you have to play on hard to get all the mission objectives, because it makes the enemies unfeasible to fight. I feel like the game shouldn't let you shoot guards with arrows if you can shoot them with 10 arrows and it doesn't kill them. Make one mistake, have to fight a guard, you're in a life and death duel, which the melee combat is actually pretty tense and fun, except there's 20 guards in the level. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495706
Adding more objectives on higher difficulties is the only good option the designers had. It's boring to just add more guards on a higher difficulty (which it does, but it's secondary to the new objectives) or the even worse option of changing their behavior. You're playing a stealth game, so the inability to kill guards is important to make sure you stay undetected and be more careful instead of: "Oh well, I was careless and got caught, time for a sword fight!" Having to get in a sword fight (or run away on difficulties that prevent killing) works, because Thief (or more accurately Thief 1) is meant to evoke tension and fear of getting caught and to stray you away from confrontation. The blackjack (note: there is no specific spot you have to hit guards with it, you can do it from any direction, even the front, provided they aren't in combat) works as a mechanic, because the choice to use it or not use it changes the way the game it played, if you knock guards out you get the burden of hiding their bodies, so other AI don't see them. And if you choose to not use the blackjack, then the only suitable playstyle is ghosting (not alerting anyone to the point where they start to search for you) which makes the game even more difficult to those who desire while also changing the way you play.
The beauty of Thief comes down to letting the player form a playstyle without having them pick a class or such, but from the game's mechanics, Thief gives you so much freedom of approach while only making restrictions when necessary.

>>9494125
>The level design looks generic, lazy, and chaotic


Vectorman is in that wired genre of game that isn't quite a run and run, and isn't quite a platformer. I generally call these types of games 'gun-formers'. Gunformers, are the types of games that feature maze like level design with lots of platforming and your primary weapon being projectile. Turrican was kinda the type of game that spawned this genre. I would say Metroid, but Metroid has too much exploration to fall into this category. Robocop vs Terminator, Judge Dredd (SNES game), Cool Spot, because you shoot all the time, Earthworm Jim 1 at least, Alien 3 Mega Drive/ Genesis, Demolition Man. I'm sure others can think of more. That's the genre I put Vectorman in, as most of the levels follow that formula. Vectorman tries to mix it up with different formulas, though. Game looks really nice, it has a generally good soundtrack (to me), the levels are good. Some bosses are cool looking. But some are way to gimicky. Like the train boss is not good. the disco stage boss where you spin around in circles is a bit lame. It's OK for one of these games. But Hard Corps is better overall. Contra III on the SNES is better. I remember playing Vectorman 2 all the way up to the half way point, but never fully completed it. Vectorman 2 is a spectacle for the hardware, with enhanced simulated lighting and bigger sprites, it is an impressive tech demo for the hardware in 1996. Anyway. Not too bad as a sequel. I feel like the levels were a little more streamlined, but the game made harder. It has the generic 3D tunnel effect stage, found in all of the Genesis/ Mega Drive games, like Garfield and batman and Robin. Also wasn't a fan of the over head stages with the rocket. I rank it as B tier series. Pixar stole the concept for Wall-E?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9493759
Lots of reasons. It's been known since forever ago that Woolsey didn't deliver the most faithful translation, not to mention all the censorship, which is why we got that old Sky Render fan translation over twenty years ago (that we now know to be amateurish as fuck). Then the GBA game came out, and its translation was recognized to be much more accurate, but it had two problems: first, by that point, Woolsey's script had obtained meme status, and while the GBA script kept some of his lines, it changed or tossed enough of them out to piss a vocal part of the fanbase off. Second, the GBA version had problems of its own, namely shit music, slowdown and lower resolution, among others. So now you have a bunch of Woolsey fanboys who like the idea of a more accurate script while still staying true to the Woolsey "flavor", all on the mostly superior SNES version, and before long, we got the Ted Woolsey Uncensored hack. Problem is, its creator didn't know a lick of moon, so all he did was mix and match bits and pieces of the Woolsey, GBA and Sky Render scripts as he pleased, and to top it off, he decided to also make it an overarching "game improvement" hack that fixed a gorillion longstanding bugs and added QoL changes. This effectively set the mold for all like-minded hacks that followed, all of which were made by people with no nip-speaking credentials, and all of which were convinced they could do it better than the last, especially given they're not constrained to just script changes, but outright game changes as well, so every new release is just feature creep. It's telling that it wasn't until like last year that we got a simple, no frills port of the GBA script to the SNES version.

tl;dr autism and one-upmanship

They don't seem to care that sometimes the best version of a film isn't the cut available on Netflix, they don't care that audio properties and subtitles can be adjusted when you have the file yourself, they don't care that audio clips can be tweaked or edited when you own the mp3, that LAN multiplayer or at least non-server based multiplayer means it's yours to play forever, etc. I admit that the trade-off is that it takes more time to set these things up than clicking Play/Download on a monthly web service, but to anyone with any serious interest in a medium the trade-offs are night and day. Unfortunately, the vast majority of people have only the slightest interest in games/film/music beyond their momentary urges for entertainment.

>>9485826
My girlfriend and I both got Covid back in November of 2020 and we were both quarantined from work for a solid four weeks. Paid, thankfully, but horribly sick for the first week and a half. I got better quicker and I occupied our time by playing Ty the Tasmanian Tiger. Now whenever snow hits our area she wants me to play it again. Plan on starting it in a few days. Other games we usually play around this time of year are Ms. Pacman Maze Madness and Spyro Enter the Dragonfly. I personally have an attachment to that game because as a kid I was really poor, and my original Spyro games had been lost and I couldn't afford to get new copies, so one of the last Christmases I had with my gram before she died, she got me a secondhand Gamecube and a few games, EtD being one of them. She knew how much I loved Spyro when I was younger, and I was happy to have any title at all again, so I played the whole game over the next few visits while she watched. Sorry for blogposting. Happy Holidays anons.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9495609
Star of David was often used as a generic magic symbol in Japan. Occult themes were a popular fad in 1970s and Japanese nerds got interested in European occult culture without properly linking it to an expected Judeo-Chrisitian background. That's why you can see a lot of magicians casually rocking the Seal of Solomon on their gear in Japanese comics, cartoons and games.

What's interesting is how programmers can implement the rules of probability.
When is the outcome determined? When you initialise the screen? Or when you make the input to confirm your choice?

Using emulation rewind functions to investigate, In Wario Land's case it appears to be the former; the winning and losing choices are pre-determined (though I didn't ascertain if all three outcomes are determined from the start, or determined with each new opportunity, nor if "correct choices" are always the same on a per-level basis).

In this video, I quickly beat the first level, and coincidentally, all three winning choices were the left bucket.
The odds of that would be one in eight though. There are only eight possible outcomes:
>Left Left Left
>Left Left Right
>Left Right Left
>Right Left Left
>Left Right Right
>Right Left Right
>Right Right Left
>Right Right Right

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490387
Meanwhile, as an example of "determined at point of decision", are the Toad Houses from Super Mario Bros 3.
The contents of the chest are determined the instant you press the button to open it. The fact there are three chests is a total illusion of choice in this regard.

The contents vary depending on which Toad house you are visiting, but the first one in the game can only give you a Super Mushroom, Fire Flower, or Super Leaf.
Whilst all are beneficial, a "Super Mushroom" can be considered the least beneficial as it only gives you one extra hit compared to two extra hits (in the international release anyway), and doesn't give you a special ability.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490402
Also worth mentioning is the level up bonus in Super Mario RPG.
It also resembles a game of chance; will your picked bonus be higher than usual?
However, it follows an entirely deterministic pattern based on which level you just reached. This can be used strategically to maximise gains.

a long time ago i used to think that the GB tetris piece selection algorithm tried to give you pieces that you "struggled" with more often. i would then spaz out I-pieces trying to game the system.
a few years ago i examined the assembly to see if i was right. in truth, the algorithm uses entropy from the noise channel in the sound subsystem to generate a candidate piece, and then tries rerolling 2 or 3 times if the piece was the same as the last.

>>9495215
If you have 100 or fewer coins when you start the minigame, and commit to the three rounds, these are your possible outcomes:
>Win, Win, Win - 800 coins (8x)
>Win, Win, Lose - 200 coins (2x)
>Win, Lose, Lose - 50 coins (0.5x)
>Lose, Lose, Lose - 12 coins (0.125x)
Note that the order of the wins or losses doesn't really matter, aside from when you halve an odd number and would lose a coin to rounding down (although if it rounds up, you would retain one more coin).

The potential gains are far higher than the potential losses, that losing three games is offset by a small win in one game.
If you set up a simulation to wager 100 coins from a pool, play three rounds and add the outcome to the pool, most of the time the pool will keep increasing providing your starting pool was large enough to weather early losses.

In Link to the Past, there is a treasure chest mini-game where you can pay 30 rupees to open two chests. I recall this is like the Toad houses where the contents are determined when the chest is opened.
I forget what the exact prize pool is, I'd have to look it up, but one of the prizes can be 100 rupees, so with each game played there is a chance to gain 70 or 100 rupees. Some of the other prizes include a smaller number of rupees, a bomb, a heart, I think an arrow, and of course a piece of heart which is the main incentive to play. Once you've received the piece of heart, that prize is removed from the pool and that increases the odds of receiving any other prize.

This mini game is a reliable source of rupees in the game due to the favourable odds, but it does rely on you having a good starting amount to weather the losses of early bad luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9495276
Actually, I found the prize pool, and this GameFAQs guide does a nice job of outlining the two other minigames I wanted to explain.
https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/snes/588436-the-legend-of-zelda-a-link-to-the-past/faqs/77032/mini-games

There are three chest mini-games:
>Verson 1 - Open 1 chest for 100 rupees
>Prize - 1 rupee (lose 99)
>Prize - 20 rupees (lose 80)
>Prize - 300 rupees (gain 200)
Your odds of gaining money is 1/3 and whilst the gain is great, the losses are harsh, and you're capped at carrying 999 rupees so this is generally not worth the risk involved.
Gaining 200 is very easily offset by losing 99 twice or 80 twice, and you can easily lose multiple times in a row. Statistically you would gain about 21 rupees every three games if you played lots of them, but the circumstances mean you'll play few and are more likely to lose out.

>Version 2 - Open 1 chest for 20 rupees
>Prize - 1 rupee (lose 19)
>Prize - 20 rupees (no change)
>Prize - 50 rupees (gain 30)
It's an even chance of winning, losing, or nothing happening, but the gains are greater than the losses, so statistically if you have the patience you should be able to keep gaining money indefinitely, but it will often be getting 11 rupees back as an offset for every 19 lost. That's not great.

>Version 3 - Open 2 chests for 30 rupees (you can get two of the same prize, Piece of Heart removed from pool)
>Prize - 1 rupee
>Prize - 50 rupees
>Prize - 100 rupees
>Prize - 1 bomb
>Prize - 1 arrow
>Prize - 10 arrows
>Prize - 1 heart
When playing this game you've got a 1/7 chance to gain 20 rupees or 70 rupees on the first chest.
This is trickier to figure out with all of the combinations available, but having two chances to gain at least 20 or 70 rupees per play by itself can make this a profitable game, offsetting the times you don't get any money out of it.

Wanted to add that the Zelda series has had these kinds of "all of nothing" gambling games from the beginning, and still continue all the way to Breath of the Wild.

In Ocarina of Time, there's that one famous mini-game where you need to pick the correct of two chests 5 times in a row. The prize is either a key to the next room, or rupees depending on how far you played.

Of course, the famous solution is to use the Lens of Truth to see what the winning chests are, so you can reach the final room and claim your prize of a piece of heart. Playing through chance, you only have a 3.125% chance of making the correct guess 5 times in a row. (50% -> 25% -> 12.5% -> 6.25% -> 3.125%).
This game isn't very exploitable, though. To play costs 10 rupees, to win will earn a purple rupee for a profit of 40.
There are much better ways to earn that amount of money, like climbing up the chains of Hyrule Castle Town's moat gate and collecting the hidden red rupees.

The Minish Cap also has a version of this game, similar to Wario Land, you double or nothing (not double or halve), and the maximum earnings are 999 rupees. The starting bet is always 10 rupees.
This game can't be cheated, and earning the maximum payout has very low odds.

In Breath of the Wild, an NPC in Lurelin village runs a three-chest all-or-nothing mini-game.
Two chests lose, and one chest wins.
You can pay 10 rupees for a chance to win a red rupee (worth 20), 50 rupees for a chance to win a silver rupee (worth 100), or 100 rupees for a chance to win a gold rupee (worth 300).
The third option represents the best opportunity for profit giving a triple payout rather than double, but it has the biggest risk.
It's not a super remarkable version of the gambling game, however the game does not allow you to manually save after making your wager, in a game that lets you save your current progress at nearly any moment. You can just save before starting the game, though, so it's still exploitable.

Yoshi's Island is a true 10/10 Nintendo platformer, and the one time they truly did right by Yoshi in his own games. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It would be the best game on SNES if:

100%ing the game wasn't made needlessly obnoxious by some bad design choices, namely having to collect everything in a level in one go, instead of only coming back for the things you missed previously, and the presence of stuff like missable red coins carried by Shy Guys that escape or one way doors and tubes that exacerbate the problem.

The extra levels weren't mostly infuriating bullshit.

The transformations weren't clunky and honestly unnecessary. It's fine when they're in self contained sub-levels when you have to fly the helicopter in the middle of a level avoiding enemies and trying to not miss collectables it's just obnoxious.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9494223
Yoshi's Island is weird because if you don't bother with the collectables you can fly through it in like 4 hours, and it's braindead easy - However, you'll also miss a lot of the best bits of design in the game.
If you DO bother with the collectables and try to 100% it, you will absolutely fucking hate Yoshi's Island by the end.

So when I play usually I just try to go for all the flowers and don't really bother with much else.

It's a great game. The fact that they just pulled that aesthetic out of the air and nailed it on the first try is remarkable to me. It also has an insanely high amount of enemies, including reintroducing Shy Guys to the Mario series which is pretty neat.

DKC and Yoshi's Island both came out relatively late in the SNES's lifespan and are both great platformers, but they're so utterly different from each other. That era was really the pinnacle of the genre for a long time.

Anyway here's a scrapped stage select that was uncovered during the gigaleak.

>Deja vu has absolutely no softlocks unless you count the glitch where you die three times in a row on the same screen and it erases your save file. They went out of their way to include failsafes.
I've actually found the softlocks in Deja Vu. I managed to run across all of them while playing the NES version as a kid. The mugger in the street and the thug in the alley are possible soft-locks. If you've already hit the mugger a few times, the next hit results in death. The only way past him after that, and the thug in the alley, is the $20 bill in your wallet(or one you steal from Sugar Shack after knocking her ass out). If you spend that $20 on a new gun to avoid another soft-lock, then you can wind up stuck with the mugger or thug with no way out.
Why buy a new gun? Because there is a random soft-lock in the sewers after you get rid of the murder weapon. I had it happen to me. After throwing away the gun, you can encounter the Alligator in the sewers. Only way to survive the gator is to shoot him. No new gun = stuck in the sewers with no way out other than death.
I actually recommend headed to the police station prior to going to the sewers just to encounter Sugar Shack, knock her out, and take her money to get yourself the new gun before going into the sewers, so you still have a $20 for the mugger, then staying out of the alley where the thug is. This way you avoid both potential soft-locks.
Another softlock happens if you enter a cab and travel but don't have the 3 coins to pay off, or leave Peoria St with less than 6 coins. Can't pay the cabbie with cash, so you get stuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484204
The SNES and the Genesis pulled about equal numbers in the North American market but that is with Sega shifting support from the Genesis to the Saturn in 94 giving the SNES 95 and 96 almost unopposed. From 91 when the Sega Genesis actually started selling in large volumes up until 94 Sega had a significant lead in the North American market. In Europe the situation was even worse for Nintendo and they never caught up at all even after Sega moved on. So often when a game was made in the west it was made with Genesis in mind and then ported to SNES. In Japan the Genesis was a footnote so in the rarer case when a game was made for both consoles it was usually SNES first and a port to Genesis to grab money from the western market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484204

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Americans were a little lacking in 68k skill compared to Europeans as there were no major consumer level 68k machines in the US. the Mac line was the only 68k machine of any importance and it was more of a productivity/educational computer and not a home computer heavily used for gaming. besides a lot of Mac software used HLLs which wasn't useful knowledge for Mega Drive coding where everything was assembly language.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9484204
I suspect that SEGA had a better relationship with American developers while Nintendo was just being Nintendo. A good example is SEGA of America offering stuff like GEMS to those unfamiliar with the sound driver while devs had to work with whatever low quality samples they had on the SNES. Games like Cool Spot had way better audio as a result. There's also Nintendo's infamous censorship policies which I'm sure extended far beyond Mortal Kombat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: That Motorolla 68000 CPU in the Genesis/ Mega Drive was a big factor in it, because many of the 16bit micro computers like the Amiga, Atari ST and Macintosh all used 16/32bit variants of that CPU. EA was primarily a PC developer before they got into the home market with the Genesis. They avoided the NES because they didn't want to be locked into a Nintendo contract. They thought the hardware was old and outdated by 1990. They used their knowledge of the 68000 CPU to reverse engineer the Genesis and make their own dev kits, and used that as a bargaining ship to get a good third party deal with Sega. Which worked., A lot of developers who came from the Amiga and Atari ST were just really familiar with the Motorolla 68000 CPU. The founder of Travellers Tales Jon Burton was an Amiga demo-scener before breaking into the console market on the Mega Drive. Also the 68000 CPU was used in a lot of 16bit arcade machines. Really common CPU for the time. It's not like the SNES was hard to use in comparison, as it uses a 16bit variant on the 6502 CPU found in the NES. Apple used this CPU in their Apple IIGS system, and the Apple II GS was also used as a dev kit for the SNES. The SNES is really not a CPU driven system, and I think everything was mostly handled by the GPU instead.

>That Motorolla 68000 CPU in the Genesis/ Mega Drive was a big factor in it, because many of the 16bit micro computers like the Amiga, Atari ST and Macintosh all used 16/32bit variants of that CPU.


The racing game Vroom for Atari ST and Amiga:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W_gGNE7u5Es&t=210s

F1 for the MD/ Genesis by Domark:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GrMMfjsYez0&t=41s


The developers at Domark basically recreated the game engine from Vroom on the Genesis. They used all the same 68000 techniques. F1 really does look just like Vroom.

Domark used the same game engine for Kawasaki Superbike, and they also made an SNES version as well. The SNES game is on the left. They tried to recreate their F1/ Kawaskai engine on the SNES, and didn't too to bad of a job. But its still displaying less polyons and less 'fake' scaling objects on the screen. The game doesn't really use any scaling sprites, it just switches between different sized sprites:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-2o1t_UyFEo


Many Euro (and some American devs) could apply many of the same CPU driven techniques on the MD/ Genesis that they learned on those computers. Though the Genesis has generally better hardware scrolling.
